newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Retail buying revives Singapore shares at close.
newsitem.headline: Retail buying revives Singapore shares at close.

text.p: Singapore stocks ended broadly firmer in robust trade on Wednesday as retail investors mopped up small-capitalised shares, dealers said.
The small-capitalised stocks included paper maker New Toyo, machine tool maker Excel Machine and healthcare group Raffles Medical. All of which touched new year highs.

New Toyo hit Singapore $0.955 before ending up S$0.055 cents at S$0.95, while Excel hit S$0.78 before settling at S$0.775, up three cents. Speculation that Raffles could be a potential takeover candidate fuelled it to a new high of S$1.01 before it ended at S$0.98, up seven cents.
The Straits Times Industrials Index ended 17.52 points down at 2,023.86, dampened by car retailer Cycle & Carriage. The issue ended 30 cents lower at S$14.80.
Infrastructure firm Van der Horst led the actives with over 25 million shares traded as investors were drawn in by its earnings prospects. It ended 21 cents up at S$2.48.
Banks were among gainers after the Monetary Authority of Singapore said on Tuesday prospects for financial services remain bright. DBS Foreign ended 50 cents up at S$18.50.
Total market volume was an active 180.8 million shares with 256 gainers to 117 losers.
